javadoc:
This class represents a major "and-able" row in the dialog's filter panel. It is associated with a single column at any given time. It has a single {@link DialogFilterConditionSet} which is typed on the ColumnType. If the column changes, it will create a new condition set for the new Column.

The {@link DialogFilterRow} and the {@link DialogFilterConditionSet} classes work together to represent a row in the dialog's filter panel. The row is untyped since the associated column can change. The {@link DialogFilterConditionSet} is typed on the column's value type which allows it to take advantage of Java's templating for type safety.

methods.name: <init>
methods.comment: Constructor with the first column selected

params.name: dialogModel
params.comment: the model that created this filter row.

params.name: logicOperation
params.comment:
the logic operation for how this filter row is combined with previous
 rows.

methods.name: <init>
methods.comment: Constructor when constructing the model from an exiting filter.

params.name: dialogModel
params.comment: the model that created this class.

params.name: columnFilter
params.comment: A column filter from the existing filter.

methods.javadoc:
Sets the column for this filter row.
@param columnData the data for the column.
methods.name: setColumnData
methods.comment: Sets the column for this filter row.

methods.name: getLogicOperation
methods.comment:
Returns the LogicOperation that specifies how this DialogFilterRow relates to
 previous rows.

methods.javadoc:
Method for the dialog to use to get the columns for the comboBox
@return all the columns available to be filtered in the table.
methods.name: getAllColumnData
methods.comment: Method for the dialog to use to get the columns for the comboBox

return.comment: all the columns available to be filtered in the table.

Gets the current ColumnData for this filter row.
@return the current ColumnData for this filter row.
methods.name: getColumnFilterData
methods.comment: Gets the current ColumnData for this filter row.

return.comment: the current ColumnData for this filter row.

methods.javadoc:
Pass through for checking filter condition validity.
@return true if valid, false otherwise.
methods.name: hasValidFilterValue
methods.comment: Pass through for checking filter condition validity.

methods.javadoc:
Returns a list of the "or-able" constraints configured for this column.
@return a list of the "or-able" constraints configured for this column.
methods.name: getFilterConditions
methods.comment: Returns a list of the "or-able" constraints configured for this column.

return.comment: a list of the "or-able" constraints configured for this column.

methods.javadoc:
Adds a new DialogFilterCondition to this filter row.
@return the newly created condition.
methods.name: addFilterCondition
methods.comment: Adds a new DialogFilterCondition to this filter row.

methods.javadoc:
Adds this columns filter configuration to the TableColumnFilter under construction.
@param tableColumnFilter the filter to add.
methods.name: addToTableFilter
methods.comment: Adds this columns filter configuration to the TableColumnFilter under construction.

name: DialogFilterRow
comment:
This class represents a major "and-able" row in the dialog's filter panel.  It is associated with
 a single column at any given time.  It has a single DialogFilterConditionSet  which is
 typed on the ColumnType. If the column changes, it will create a new condition set for the new
 Column.

  The DialogFilterRow and the DialogFilterConditionSet classes work together to
 represent a row in the dialog's filter panel.  The row is untyped since the associated column can
 change.  The DialogFilterConditionSet is typed on the column's value type which allows
 it to take advantage of Java's templating for type safety.
